title: IMBUE - font id
content:
Looking for an ID on the sans serif font used for IMBUE

Many thanks in advance,  
Danny

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140418080725im_/http:/typophile.com/files/2c902fe4569e2937fdcb2aa2b969ec7c_4794.jpg)

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [2c902fe4569e2937fdcb2aa2b969ec7c.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20140418080725/http:/typophile.com/files/2c902fe4569e2937fdcb2aa2b969ec7c.jpg) | 130.28 KB |
author: Danny_Miller

comments.content: Maybe better help with this image: [http://tundrablog.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/DD\_Imbue\_3\_905.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20140418080725/http:/tundrablog.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/DD_Imbue_3_905.jpg "http://tundrablog.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/DD\_Imbue\_3\_905.jpg")

I think the middle arm of the E is a bit longer than your sample, but otherwise [Egon Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20140418080725/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/tipografiaramis/egon-sans/?refby=bowfin) looks pretty close. Of course only the M and E give us anything to work with.

- Mike Yanega

Hard to say. Very neutral, nothing really distinctive part of this /M. Can't explain also why but it feels hand-drawn/amateurish and most probably intentionally. Anyway, I'd probably start with [Maven](http://web.archive.org/web/20140418080725/http:/vissol.co.uk/mavenpro).

‘Can't explain also why but it feels hand-drawn/amateurish and most probably intentionally.’

Maybe it is details like the transitions of curves to straight lines in the U that make it look amateurish? Especially in the image provided by Adam it looks as if these are just attached circles without any optical corrections. The horizontal strike in the middle of B looks funny to. The upper outline seems to be slightly diagonal instead of horizontal. Or something is wrong with the transition from straight to curve.
